segments.text: The format is that you're going to ask me questions and I'll go on talking as long as I think it worthwhile.
That's right.
And if you think I've said too much, just stop me.
And if you think I'm missing anything in asking questions, just interject something.
Yes, sure.
OK. All right.
Now, was the study of geophysics accidental due to a need for a job in the Depression or a long-time interest of yours?
I started life as a physicist in Cambridge.
and I did the ordinary undergraduate course in physics, and I was determined to be a physicist.
And this was an ambition which I'd had since I was first a teenager, since the age of 12 or 14.
I think it first started probably earlier than that.
I thought I'd be an engineer, and then I learned what the world was like, and I decided to be a physicist.
And I was, from the first really, a serious professional physicist.
in the Cambridge tradition of experimental physics.
And then I started to do research in 1929, which is not the best time in the world to start.
I started on a PhD and I was going along and I was working on the scattering of electrons in gases.
That's quite irrelevant to your topic, but this came out very well and rather quickly.
Things were going well, Rutherford seemed pleased, he wasn't frightfully interested in this particular project.
My supervisor was Patrick Blackett, who comes in later in the story again.
And then one day I was having tea in the Cavendish, and a man came up to me and said, do you want a job in Geodesy?
And I said, I think I probably do, what's Geodesy?
This was Norman Feather, I think, who was recently retired as professor of physics in Edinburgh.
A very bright young man who never really came to all that.
Well, anyway, he'd been offered the job and he decided he didn't want it.
And I went to see Rutherford.
And Rutherford said, look, there are an awful lot of people just in front of you.
And I think, and there are no jobs at all.
If I were you, I'd take any job I could get.
And so I went off and saw the man who was teaching surveying actually, a man called Sir Gerald Lance Cunningham.
He had been in the British Army in India as a surveyor.
He'd spent his life, he was a man then, I forget how old he was, I wrote a biography of him actually, and he was probably sixty.
He'd been a surveyor in India and then come back to Cambridge to teach surveying.
I think I needn't go into this because, as I say, I've written a biography of him in the Royal Society's biographical notices.
And he seemed a rather nice sort of man, quite uninstructed, obviously didn't know anything about anything.
He was a soldier and so on.
Ended up as a colonel, I think, which isn't a very elevated rank.
I thought I'd give it a try.
So I took this job, and I dickered with him a bit, and I got him to pay me 350 pounds a year, which was very good pay in those days.
I've never felt so well off as I did in this job.
I had 350 as a salary, I had 150 by miscellaneous coaching and teaching and helping in labs and things.
And I had about 100 pounds of my own, and I had something like 600 pounds altogether.
And I've never been so well off.
We had help in the house.
We had everything.
We went skiing in the winter in Switzerland, and we went to Austria in the summer.
And I got married, and everything was fine.
And if you work it out with the inflation and the changes in taxes and so on, you'll find I was, in fact, better off than I've ever been since, until I came here.
Anyway, I took this job, and a day or two later, I met Rutherford.
Rutherford, of course, was the great father figure of physics at this time, a man with a wonderful instinct.
Someone said of him, the alpha particles were his friends.
He knew what they'd do.
Well, he met me in the street, and he said, how are you getting on?
I said, all right.
He said, well, but how are you getting on with this man that's cunning him?
And I said, I'm getting on very well.
He's a nice man.
He said, yes.
I know he's a nice man.
He's not very inspiring, is he?
And I said, no, you couldn't call him that.
He said, well, never your mind.
If you want anything, just come and see me.
He knew his, he was a modest man in a way, but he knew his position in the scheme of things.
Well, anyway, that's how I got out of physics and into geophysics.
And there was no money at all.
In one year during this period, our department had no money other than they could pay my salary.
Lennox Cunningham they didn't pay, he was paid by Trinity College and we had no money at all.
And I went out and got contracts to do things for various firms and we got along and started serious work.
And looking back I'm surprised how much we got done between 1931 when I joined this enterprise and 1939 when war broke out.
That was eight years.
And we started off, of necessity, doing what we were able to do, what we had equipment for.
Ernest Cunningham had designed and constructed a pendulum apparatus for measuring gravity.
And I took this up and the first thing I did was to make the thing work.
He'd never succeeded in getting it to work.
And so we got the thing to work.
And essentially my PhD thesis was in two halves.
The first half was on the scattering of solar electrons and gases.
Looking back, I was reading it the other day and I thought it was an admirable thesis.
about a topic which was very important at the time.

Quantum mechanics was essentially invented in the middle 20s and I started on this work in 29 and we showed that quantum mechanics could account for the processes of scattering and this was one of the things that the old quantum theory of Bohr couldn't do.
So very early on I
got serious scientific results and a little bit of a reputation.
Well, then the second half of the thesis consisted of an account of how to measure gravity with pendulums.
And in between, there was a piece on the theory of the scattering of neutrons.
I suddenly became interested in quantum mechanical scattering theory.
And then there was an appendix on a machine for solving differential equations.
Well, if never, no university in the world would accept a thesis today with a sort of ragbag of things.
My examiners were Chadwick, the discoverer of the neutron, and Patrick Blackett, who was my supervisor.
Look, I'm going into much too much detail of the part before I became an oceanographer.
No, but no.
Do you like this?
Yes, I have all kinds of questions here to ask you about this that you're just answering as you go along.
As you can see, I'm marking them off.
Shall I go on like this?
You bet.
Well, I remember the Ph.D.,
oral very well.
In Cambridge, just the two examiners and the candidate go to the oral.
And I went in, and the first thing Chandwick said was, you see that thing over by the door?
What is it?
And I said, well, I don't know.
It's kept that door open ever since I can remember.
It was a big lump, some big lump of iron, some sort of machine.
Oh, he said, you won't know what that is.
That's the machine which Wollaston made in 1812 for making Wollaston wire.
Whether it was true or not, I don't know how he knew.
And then Blackett said, do you read the Times this morning?
And I said no.
And he said, well, there's a letter in it about the distances of stars.
How do you find the distances of stars?
And it still happens.
I talked about this, so I've stopped.
And in all these sorts of examination interviews for jobs and things, I always believe in going on talking until someone stops you.
Because as long as they listen to you, and they're talking about something you know about, obviously you're doing all right.
And you reduce the time they've got to ask you questions you don't know about.
Well, then Blackett said, what good do you think your work is?
And I talked about that, and that was the end of my PhD all.
So this was very satisfactory.
Well then, I started to branch out a bit.
We got some money, and I went to East Africa.

with my wife and travelled all over the places you couldn't go now, all over Kenya and Uganda, south part of the Sudan, round into the Ture Forest in the Congo, down to the west of Rwenzori, back into Uganda and through Uganda again and Kenya and down into Tanzania and down to the coast and then up the coast to Malindi.

measuring gravity a great adventure one of the sort of formative things in my life that first gave me the idea that I could do what I wanted to do and all this time I was getting rather dubious telegrams and letters from Dennis Cunningham who had various objections to the way the work was being done it involved him doing something in Cambridge making some measurements in Cambridge and me making measurements in Africa and he became
sort of disenchanted with the project, didn't believe it was going to work out.
But I was pretty sure it was all right.
And when I got back, it was all right.
And then someone told me that when you're a young man, you should write a very long paper.
Because then, no one will read it, but whatever you do afterwards, people will say, very sound man, you know, he wrote that long paper.
So I settled down, and I wrote the longest paper that had been published in the Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society in this century.
And it stayed the longest until after the war when there was a friend of mine who wrote a paper on the internal ballistics of rockets that was longer.
So that I then become, this is the prestigious journal in England, rather stuffy, large sized pages, and this had coloured maps everywhere.

I was a slightly erratic character who might well be accused of getting things wrong and rushing into print and so on, but the best thing to do was to have something at any rate people would say, yes this was a sound piece of work.
Well then I felt we had to branch out and I took up seismic work on land.
This was the time when seismology with explosions was just coming
And it was something of a mystery.
The oil industry weren't saying very much, and in fact, weren't doing it very well.
And we started from scratch.

With a number of graduate students, I mean usually only one at a time, because I never had more than one graduate student at a time at this time, through a number of years, four or five years, we worked on the depth of the old rocks under East England.

In East England you've got old rocks a few hundred feet down, a thousand feet down, overlaid by clays and chalk and such things, and we were mapping this old land surface now bedded under East England.
It was, we bit off more than we could chew, rather, but we couldn't quite acknowledge that, and we kept at it.
And I really learned about seismology because, as I say, we were starting more or less from scratch.
We wrote another very large paper on this.
And then, at the, you, what would you take me?
Sir?
Do you want to put a new tape in?
No, no.
Well, at the International Union of Geologists and Geophysics in Edinburgh in 1936, this was about five years after I started in geophysics, I met Dick Field.
Dick Field is one of the most influential geologists of the century.
He was at Princeton.
He never did very much scientific work, really.
He never published very many papers.
He was a curious man, extremely eccentric, extremely uninhibited.
He was the most frightful nuisance.
He wouldn't stop talking.
He wouldn't take no for an answer.
He went on and on.
And he started going on and on about the importance of doing something about the geology of the oceans.
Well, we were already doing something about gravity measurement at sea.
There was a man called Vaning Minus, a wonderful man at Dutchman, who devised a method of using pendulums in a submarine for measuring gravity at sea.
And Minus had come over, and we'd made arrangements to borrow his apparatus.
And a colleague of mine, a young man, had joined us.
He wasn't a graduate student because he didn't think it suitable for a gentleman to take a PhD.
There was a strong feeling at that time in Cambridge that a gentleman didn't take a PhD.
In fact, you don't want the history of the PhD in Cambridge.
It's a very curious story.
Yes.
As a matter of fact, I was going to ask you what was life like as a student at Cambridge 45 years ago.
Well, let me tell you about that.
The PhD, of course, was invented in Germany as a second degree, after you got your first degree.
And they didn't have one in Cambridge.
But a considerable number of people started to come from various countries in the empire, particularly Canada, Australia, New Zealand, to turn up in Cambridge.
And it was obviously desirable that they should have something to show for it, some certificate or other.
So they took up the German idea of having a PhD, and four, these people with a Cambridge degree were not eligible.
The argument was that if you had a Cambridge BA, why should you want a PhD?
And after all, you'd get an MA by paying five pounds.
In Cambridge, if you have a BA, after three years, you can pay five pounds and get an MA.
And you don't have to stay in Cambridge.
You can go away and get a job somewhere and just send in your five pounds and you get your MA.
And as far as I know, that's all so.
Well, anyway, so there was a PhD for people from abroad.
And Rutherford was the first man to get it in, I think, 1896 or thereabouts.
So they started with a bank.
And this became a very popular thing.
And after the war, there was a feeling that people from Cambridge should also be able to take it.
And in fact, Chadwick was persuaded to take it to give some prestige to the degree.
Chadwick came to Cambridge just after the war.
He had, I think, a Cambridge degree already.
He'd been imprisoned in Germany during the war.
He was a
He was in Germany, having just taken his degree before the war, and was shut up in Ruhleben, I think it was, a camp he was interned in Ruhleben.
And he met there a number of other people, including Charlie Ellis, who became a famous physicist in Cambridge.
And Shantwick ran a course in physics in this Ruhleben camp.
the wall.
After the war he came back and he was asked if he would take the PhD in order to give some prestige to it from the point of view of Englishmen taking it.
Well right up to the middle 30s there was quite a strong feeling that it was slightly not the thing for a man with a Cambridge degree to take a PhD.
Blackett never took a PhD.
This man, BC Brown, who took up gravity measuring in submarines, never took a PhD.
A number of people didn't.
I went against this.
I said, I am going to have all the qualifications I can get, because I don't know what's going to happen in the future.
And I may need them for some reason, and they can't do me any harm.
After all, I don't have to call myself Dr. Bullard.
I can just keep it in the background.
Well, anyway, if you asked me just now,
say something about what it was like to be a student in Cambridge.
Well, so I should go back, I think, to my first arrival in Cambridge.
You'll find some account of this in that piece I wrote about Rutherford.
which I gave you.
I wrote in Nature last year a piece about Rutherford's Cambridge.
I was asked to write a light-hearted piece.
Nature has one issue a year which isn't so serious-minded at the time of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, and I wrote a piece about the Cavendish.
Well, in Cambridge,
you had to take four scientific subjects for your first two years.
And I took physics, maths, mineralogy, and chemistry.
And so I was only giving a rather small part of my time to physics.
And these first two years were something of a disappointment.
The lectures were moderately good.
People were obviously preoccupied with their own research and so on, and they were a little superficial.
And I remember in my third year coming out of a lecture by Aston, the inventor of the mass spectrograph.
He was lecturing on mass spectroscopy.
And I met Blackett in the corridor.
He's a man 10 years older than me, already a very distinguished physicist.
He said, what are you doing?
I said, I've been listening to old Aston.
He said, well, Aston, you do that for us.
It's all in his book.
And suddenly it came to me with a blinding flash that this was true of all the lecturers.
So I stopped going to lectures altogether in my third year.
There was no compulsion to go.
And the examinations were not on the lectures.
The examinations were on physics and were set largely by people from outside Cambridge, so they had no necessary relation to the lectures.
So there was no great advantage in going to the lectures.
So I continued to go to
Rutherford's lectures, of course they were fun.
You never knew what he'd say next.
He had this wonderful intuitive understanding of physics and this pose of not knowing anything about theoretical physics.
In fact, although he wasn't a mathematician, he was rather shrewd about physics and he had this wonderful intuition of how things would work and he'd say the most outrageous things.
I think
probably intentionally.
I remember once him saying, integral y dx, dx is small, we'll ignore this, that kind of thing.
And somehow or other the answer always came out right in the end.
There's a story that
In one of his early papers, I don't know if this is true, he was measuring the charge on the alpha particle, and it came out as 3.4.
And he said, we'll take the nearest integer, which is 4, because he knew by some obscure internal intuition that this was the right answer.
Well, anyway, he was the most wonderful man, and I got to know him when I started to do research.
He was a predictable man in some cases.
Sometimes he'd come in and he'd be as nice as anything, and then suddenly when he'd come in in a bad temper, he'd have to work it off from the first man he met.
There was a man called Roberts, who was I suppose ten years older than me, working in the same room, and he came in one day, apparently very good humour, rubbing his hands, and said,
The time has come to consider whether your experiments are worth the liquid air they consume.
And Paul Roberts, who was a shy and retiring man with an enormous admiration of Rutherford, was absolutely shattered by this.
Another day, he came in, and I had asked the head lab man to move an induction heater downstairs because I wanted to use it.
And the lab man had complained to Rutherford that people were wanting this thing moved up and down stairs.
Rutherford, as his usual way, he didn't put up a notice or anything, he just came around and attacked some individual, which is a very effective way, you see, of preventing people doing things.
He started talking to me about it, and he worked himself up gradually by saying when he was young there hadn't been such things and no one used them, and so on and so forth.
And finally he said, I never want to see you in the lab again.
Which is a little high, I thought, on a graduate student in his second year.
So Oliphant came to defend me, and Oliphant got told off for some quite other thing.
And then he went round and he found Cockroft, the inventor of artificial disintegration, who designed the machine.
He told him off for not making it in two parts, that it would be carried downstairs.
And that evening I heard he was dining in Trinity, and
He met the man, or he thought he'd met the man, who invented induction heaters from General Electric.
And he said to him, he said, do you let your young men have these machines carried up and downstairs all the time?
And the other man said, no, we have one on each floor.
Well, anyway, I arranged next morning to get in a little early, because Motherford always arrived on the dot of nine.
And I met him at the door and walked upstairs with him.
And there must have been some feeling that he'd said something unsuitable because he was so nice to me and, you know, really friendly.
And it was really the first time I really got to know him.
I mean, I was entirely aware that he didn't really intend to throw me out of the room.
It was a very curious set-up.
There was no equipment at all, practically.
You made everything yourself.
You did your own glassblowing.
Great difficulty in getting any kind of equipment.
Rutherford was a farmer's boy.
At least, he was a farmer's boy, a small farm in New Zealand.
And he regarded himself as a farmer's boy who had somehow fallen into a corrupt society.
And this gave him the right to be rude to people.
He was really extraordinarily rude to a great number of people.
But no one minded.
He sort of went booming on.
And obviously, he didn't feel he was being rude.
One day, the master of Corpus Christi College, which was across a little alleyway from the lab, complained about the noise that was being made in the lab by a piece of equipment.
And Rutherford was telling this story.
He said, I told him if he didn't like the noise, he shouldn't have built the college there.
The college, of course, was built in the 15th century or something, this guy.
Well, the kind of atmosphere was this rather tough atmosphere, tremendously competitive, of course, because this was clearly the best school of physics in the world.
This was the great centre of physics, where nuclear physics was invented.
So the result was you got tremendously bright students,
And the tremendously competitive atmosphere, very few jobs about.
I remember Lord Bowden telling me, who was principal of the Manchester College of Technology.
He was made a lord for some obscure reason by Mr. Wilson, who I suppose threw him out.
Mr. Wilson used to make people lords either when he owed them money or when he threw them out of his government.
Anyway, Bogle said, you know, it took me years to realise that the fact I wasn't as bright as these people didn't mean I had a low IQ, that this was a selective group.
Well, anyway, I got out of this
And everyone sympathized with me.
People came around and said, well, a terrible thing that you have to leave physics and go into this backwater.
And it's one of the curious and critical things in my life that I did get out of this intensely competitive atomic physics, nuclear physics that was just growing.
I thought of it as a disaster at the time.
But at the same time, I knew I was moving into something that might well suit me better.
I described this, I think, in the Ewing piece, the piece I wrote about Ewing.
I think I was really writing about myself.
It was in a speech.
It's not in, I think, in the biography of Ewing.
I wrote it in a speech I gave in New York, which will be published in a while, when I said that it was not the obvious thing to get out of being a physicist.
Ewing was also a physicist.
get out of being a physicist and go into a sideline of this sort, and particularly Earth Sciences was at a very low ebb.
The Earth Sciences had got themselves into a rut.
The essential trouble was that they had no global theories.
The global theories they had clearly didn't work and they'd become disreputable.
If you talk to any
geologist about how things worked, what the mechanisms of mountain formation were, what the driving forces of geology were, they would be quite uninterested and hostile.
Because all efforts at explanation had not got anywhere, and they'd come to believe that the progress of the science was in going to a smaller and smaller scale,
You got a PhD by examining a few square miles of whales or something of this sort.
And this had become so dull that they weren't getting bright people.
And the subject was slowly dying.
And what happened to both Ewing and myself was that we were driven largely by economic necessity.

And partly my emotional feelings, I think that something a little in the open air, something a little more large scale, a little more connected with human interests than nuclear physics, was maybe our thing.
I mean, I wouldn't have voluntarily have left physics, I don't think, but I had an idea that maybe I'd have fun with it, with the different things.
And also, of course, there's something to be said for being a large fish in a small pond.
So anyway, I made this transition in the middle of my PhD period and started off in this impoverished apartment, there was this man named Cunningham,
And there was a really good man, Harold Jeffries, who was a loner, a theoretical physicist.
He started as a botanist, actually, and then came to Cambridge and did mathematics.
And he was a theoretical physicist, a man who had great difficulty in explaining himself verbally, a very bad lecturer.
And he was nominally a member of the department, but he never turned up, actually.
I mean, I never saw him.
we had one or two in the department, it was one or two rooms, and I really never saw him there.
But he became, after a year or so, he became attached to me and to my wife.
He was a lonely man who had made many attempts to get married unsuccessfully to very unsuitable women.
He used to ask
girls from the theatrical companies that visited Cambridge, always two at a time, to come to tea with him.
And it must have been a joke, I think, among the touring companies of England, because they always came, apparently.
These rather elegant young women would come and have tea with Harold Jeffreys.
And his rooms were very odd.
He lived in college, and his rooms, he had deck chairs.
I don't quite know why, in his rooms.
